question: Mr. Rodman...it's too bad your client didn't show as much sense in choosing what he planted as he did in choosing his attorney... Lately the only variation I'm hearing in your argument is the name of the client. And you can sit there all day arguing the ins and outs of Illinois v. Gates, but you aren't going to convince me that this country has not sanctioned the use of anonymous informants. Furthermore, there is no sacred protection of property rights in the United Sates. When you make the decision to have marijuana on your farm, whether it's one joint or an acre of plants, your property can be seized and your property can be sold. Mr. Rodman, may I offer a piece of advice? The next time you argue this point before this court, regardless of my whereabouts, I recommend you have something up your sleeve other than your arm.
answer: What do you think it is?

question: Depends who it's from.
answer: Your friends at Warren, Putnam and Hudson.

question: You can learn a lot about somebody from this stuff. Three categories
answer: What would a law firm want from the new drug Czar?

question: Depends on the state.
answer: Arizona.

question: Medicinal marijuana initiative. Or am I being cynical?
answer: Maybe there's a book in it.

question: Is there a problem?
answer: No. There's no problem.

question: Okay. I see. How much do you want? You want more than this? You want something else?
answer: Drop the package. Put your hands behind your head. You're under arrest.

question: I don't understand. I think there must be some mistake.
answer: No, there's no mistake.

question: No, there's no mistake.
answer: What's your name?

question: Javier Rodriguez.
answer: Well, Javier Rodriguez, you've done a very good job, but we'll take care of it from here. We've been following these Narco- trafficantes for some time but had not been able to bring them to justice. Put the prisoners in the car. Impound the truck. One question. How did you find about this?

question: An informant.
answer: What is the name of your informant?

question: It was an anonymous tip.
answer: For a State Police officer, you're very well informed. Let's go.

question: No telltales. Nothing to read. Not touching my face. Not even blinking. No giveaways. How're you feeling?
answer: I feel good.

question: No more pissant basin league bullshit for us, hunh?
answer: Nope.

question: Father of Greek tragedy? Anyone? Okay, Aeschylus it is. His trilogy? The Oresteia. I mean this is beautiful, can anyone stop the Seth Machine? Score. Thank you. Madmax from Omaha we own you. And Tragedy is closed out.
answer: Entertainment. The Susan Lucci section or Banal Love Songs of the Nineties?

question: Banal Love Songs it is. Hey, you wanna try something?
answer: What are you doing?

question: Just watch. Inhale the smoke and hold it.
answer: What is this, like freebase?

question: Not like. It is. Go... Go! Hold it. See... Now, you see.
answer: More.

question: Jeff, you want to excuse us for a minute? Functionaries. Nice people, the Schedule C's. About twelve graduate degrees apiece, but it seems sometimes all they do is start rumors.
answer: You've done a fine job here, Sir. The Office of National Drug Control Policy is in better shape than when you found it.

question: I'm not sure I made the slightest difference. I tried... I really did.
answer: There are a lot of encouraging statistics. The work's just started, but I intend to see it through. You've got my word on that.

question: You're here for two years, three maximum. What'd they promise you? Court appointment? What? District? Appeals? Not Supreme... Supreme?
answer: I've come in to do a tough job and that's what I'm going to focus on.

question: The police won't find your car.
answer: But you're the police.

question: Call this man, he'll find your car for you.
answer: How will this guy know who has our car?

question: The police will tell him.
answer: Because we pay him, stupid. Right? And he pays the police.

question: Duck salad?
answer: Mmm.

question: Helena, you never order duck salad.
answer: Well, that's true. I don't. I think someone else is asking for it.

question: Well, he's got good taste. Isn't it the most wonderful thing you ever tasted? I mean ever.
answer: It's delicious --

question: Looking for a nice sauce ala orange. You mean all breast, just like you. Jealous, that's all --
answer: I've heard... I can't remember where... That it's full of that good kind of fat, the kind you're supposed to eat -- And now there's a good cholesterol and bad cholesterol. Everything they tell you completely changes every other week. I don't know why they think we should listen at all.

question: What I know is ducks, as cute as they are, were designed by God to be eaten.
answer: I'll put this in the back.

question: I'll put this in the back.
answer: No --

question: All the professionals keep them in the trunk.
answer: Not Tiger Woods.

question: You're looking pretty good for an old guy.
answer: My work keeps me young.

question: Which part, getting terrorists loose on bail or freeing convicted murderers on technicalities?
answer: The worst serial killer in history - who? Gacy - right? Killed forty two people. Our government killed fifty thousand in Vietnam and lied about it every day.

question: Michael, you represent drug dealers, not civil libertarians.
answer: We kidnapped Noriega out of Panama. Is that covered in your Constitution? Because it isn't in mine.

question: Noriega is a criminal.
answer: Noriega was head of a sovereign nation who made the mistake of doing business with the U.S. Government. So, no, I don't have a problem waking up every day and fighting our government, fighting people like you, trying to keep this system a little bit honest.

question: Last I read your clients were chopping people up with chainsaws and delivering illegal narcotics into this country.
answer: I hope when you were on the bench, Judge Wakefield, you didn't handle the presumption of innocence in the same fashion.

question: You planning on going somewhere, Eduardo? You don't like it here? This is the best situation you're going to have for a long, long time.
answer: I am a legitimate business. Fishing boats. Tuna. Check it out. Tax records, everything --

question: Listen you motherfucker, you tried to kill me with a fucking cannon.
answer: You can't visit me here. I want my lawyer.

question: Hello. Hello. I'm sorry, Jonas. I don't care if that is the price you have gotten in order countries. This is America, a different country. I am Carl, a different man. So you see, everything about our situation is different and I believe the pricing will be different, too. You're a reasonable man... So take the weekend to think about it. Every day with this guy is like starting all over again. Hi.
answer: Hi.

question: What's up?
answer: Just watching you.

question: I got that. How was your day? You all right?
answer: I keep feeling like I'm forgetting something. David, come inside --

question: Javier Rodriguez. Twenty-nine years- old. Graduated from Montessori school. Five years as a beat cop in TJ. Three years with the State Police. Parents died four years ago in their apartment from carbon monoxide poisoning because they could not afford to fix their gas heater. Your sister works in a Maquiladora in Juarez, making designer blue-jeans. On the police force three years, you currently make 316 dollars a month. That's your past. I want to talk about your future. Would you be willing to do something for me?
answer: If I can.

question: I'm trying to bust the Tijuana Cartel.
answer: What is it you want me to do?

question: A small thing. Nothing really.
answer: Does this offer include my partner?

question: Only if he can be trusted.
answer: He'll do what I say.

question: As it happens, the President of the United States, my new boss, the leader of the free world, has me penciled in for some "face time".
answer: Will we get invited to the White House?

question: I don't know.
answer: How long's the job?

question: Helena, I'm so sorry --
answer: Arnie, thank God. Can you please tell me what on earth is going on?

question: I understand. You're upset. You want to know what's going on. That's good.
answer: Why are you talking like that?

question: Listen to me carefully. First of all, Carl isn't here. DEA's got him and they'll hang on to him until arraignment, which will probably be tomorrow. So here you're wasting your time. Are you with me? Good. From now on I want you to expect that every word you utter will be tape-recorded, that the movement of your lips is being read. Got it?
answer: Arnie, this is crazy.

question: Got it? Good. Do not discuss anything over the telephone. Do not talk to the neighbors. Stay out of your yard.
answer: What is he being charged with?

question: I don't know, but under no circumstances would I talk about it here. I want you to go home and relax the best you can. Continue your life as if nothing has happened. That is very important.
answer: Arnie, I feel like Alice stepping through the looking glass.

question: What do we do? Okay. Fucked-up Bowman's turning blue. Doctor. We need a doctor.
answer: Your dad's a doctor. Call him --

question: He's a research doctor. You're dad's a doctor, too --
answer: What kind of research?

question: Mapping the fucking pig genome. We'll call your dad, he's a neurosurgeon --
answer: It's three a.m. I'm not supposed to be here. I snuck out --

question: ...How old are you?
answer: Sixteen

question: Live with your parents?
answer: Yes.

question: Parents still together?
answer: Yes.

question: Do you work?
answer: I volunteer. I read to blind people. One day a week for two hours.

question: In school?
answer: Cincinnati Country Day.

question: Private?
answer: Yeah.

question: How are your grades?
answer: I'm third in my class.

question: What's that mean?
answer: I get A's. All A's.

question: You do? What else you do?
answer: I'm a National Merit Finalist. I'm on the Hi-Q team and the Math team. I'm in the Spanish Club. I'm a Thespian. I'm Vice-President of my class. I'm on the volleyball team.

question: Oh, honey. Are you all right?
answer: Did you tell Dad?

question: Not yet.
answer: Are you going to?

question: I don't know.
answer: Is this bad for him?

question: They're whispering. I can't hear them, but I know it. I smell conspiracy. I feel the lie vibrating out of the home.
answer: She ain't in on it.

question: I have dreams about this, actual dreams about busting the top people, the rich people, the white people.
answer: I'm telling you, she doesn't know shit.

question: She knows Arnie Metzger.
answer: So does half of San Diego.

question: I think she's lying.
answer: Me, too.

question: We'll ground her, clip her wings a bit. School and scheduled activities and that's it until further notice. This has to be handled delicately. Dan Kelly, in the District Attorney's office, will probably help us out, quietly. Christ, this could be embarrassing.
answer: Honey, this is difficult, but we've all had our moments. I tried --

question: Stop. You experimented in college. I don't want to hear about that.
answer: Should we take the quotes off experiment and call it what it is?

question: This is different.
answer: Why?

question: To begin with, she's only sixteen years-old.
answer: I think she has to find out for herself, on her own. We have to allow her space --

question: Space for what? To O.D. like that other kid? I will not send the message that this type of behavior is okay with her parents. Because it isn't. Correct?
answer: We don't want to push her away. These are growing experiences.

question: How long have you known about this? How long have you known?
answer: Six months. I found some marijuana, that's all. And a little pipe about two inches long. I talked with her. She said her friends smoked pot and drank --

question: Explain to me how you could think that I shouldn't know about this. Explain to me how this wouldn't be relevant to me. As a parent.
answer: She asked me not to.

question: I appreciate you coming in so early.
answer: Judge Wakefield, it's an honor to handle it for you. Consider it gone away. She's a minor; it probably would've expunged on her 18th birthday anyway.

question: Still, this was a sensitive issue for me and I wanted to thank you personally.
answer: Like I said, open container, P.I., Misdemeanor possession. Easy to make it disappear. For you, poof, it's gone. One thing bothers me... That kid they dropped off had coke and heroin in him. Serious amounts. He's lucky he lived. So I gotta ask

question: I don't know what you mean.
answer: I mean, did you ask her? What kind of drugs has she tried?

question: I... I don't really know.
answer: Is she in any kind of therapy... professional help?

question: No, of course not. She's one of the top students at her school.
answer: Well, I hope it stays that way.

question: You should see little Montel play. Little Montel is the next Maradona.
answer: Maradona is a cokehead. Hand of God, my ass. We're wasting our time here.

question: He won. He was a winner. That bothers you.
answer: Winners don't do coke. Or haven't you been reading the bumper stickers?

question: Yeah, this is fun.
answer: Please put down my son.

question: Shouldn't let your kid wander off with strangers.
answer: Thank you. That's a valuable lesson. David, come on.

question: A group of us are going out tonight.
answer: Who?

question: Guzman, Tomas, Esteban --
answer: Your new friends.

question: Yeah. It should be fun. You wanna come?
answer: Not this time.

question: In my home I have B&W speakers. I recently purchased a compact disc burner. I can make my own cd's, with whatever music I like, as if I bought them at the store, only I don't have to pay these crazy prices.
answer: We have much in common. We both attended school in the United States, and both of our fathers are engineers.

question: I got into stereo equipment when I was a kid. Some people don't notice the difference but it is very important to me.
answer: Of course it is. Have some more wine. Now, Francisco, my friend... I must know where these men are who killed my captains. Not where they were last week, but where they are today, and better still, tomorrow. You are clever. You can predict where they will be, can't you?

question: This has worked for years and it will continue to work for years. NAFTA makes everything more difficult for you. The border is disappearing. You people are like those Japanese soldiers left behind on deserted islands who think that World War II is still going on. Let me be the first to tell you, your government surrendered this war a long time ago.
answer: This attitude's not gonna help him any, is it?

question: I got greedy. I decided to bring a little in on my own and somebody tipped you off. That was my mistake. Carl would never be so stupid.
answer: He hired you. That was a mistake.

question: The busiest land border crossing in the world. Over forty-one thousand vehicles per day, twenty-two thousand pedestrians on foot. I think we do a pretty good job but we know a lot of drugs are still getting through.
answer: Any idea how much?

question: I've read official estimates but I wouldn't bet my house on them. I've heard the entire cocaine supply for the United States can fit into four tractor-trailers. At least a half-dozen of those cars right out there are carrying a load of dope, with drivers employed by people who don't give a damn if they're caught or not.
answer: What do you look for?

question: We ask questions and measure the answers. When something doesn't ring true, a fact that doesn't make sense, a slight hesitation, then it's off to secondary for a closer look. Before NAFTA we had about 1.9 million trucks a year. Now it's almost double. Pretty soon there'll be Mexican truck companies that will have as much freedom in crossing the border as American truck companies.
answer: Any way we can do it better?

question: Sure. More money in intelligence on their side of the border. So we have a better idea who we're looking for. More dogs. More people. Supposed to be getting some giant x- ray machines to run the trucks through. Outside of martial law that's about the best you're gonna do. But, I should tell you, there are two things that really have us on edge right now. In the last six months seizures have tripled, even though we're pulling over the same number of cars. What does that tell you?
answer: That triple the amount of stuff is going through.

question: Anna. What's wrong? What do you want?
answer: I can't find Manolo.

question: He's not here.
answer: He never came home last night. Was he with you?

question: No.
answer: I'm worried. Last time he was out late, I went through his clothes while he was asleep.

question: I'll find him. What the fuck are you doing? You're supposed to be at work. Look at you.
answer: It's no problem. I was just with everybody we work with.

question: Oh, really. General Salazar was there?
answer: No, but a lot of other people. You should come. You should come out with us.

question: You know my dad takes eight red cold pills every day? He and my mom have cocktail hour every night, from six to seven, set your clock, two bourbons --
answer: Maybe we could show up and smoke a little rock with them to unwind --

question: Yeah, then some dope to take the edge off at the end of a long day.
answer: Have you done your homework, honey?

question: Yes, mom --
answer: Then here's a little bump.

question: Drugs weren't even a problem until a hundred years ago when the white men in power declared them a problem. Opiates. But, who was using 'em? Chinese immigrants. Slave labor. And the darkies up in the inner cities dancing to them evil rhythms of ju- ju music. People on the fringe. Artists. Decadent rich people. And who got scared? White men in power. Who's scared today? White men in power. If J.P. Morgan and John D. Rockefeller ever admitted using, it'd be a whole different story.
answer: What you want?

question: 911, and the come down.
answer: How much?

question: We'd like room 205. I love this place. Did Courtney Love play Nancy in Syd and Nancy?
answer: I think so. If she didn't she should have. I've only got maybe an hour. Then volleyball practice is over and I have to be home.

question: Why? Nobody's there.
answer: The maid... They ask her what time I get back. She spies for them. I wish we could stay here. Just be here forever and ever. Make it a little home.

question: I want to have sex and do a hit right as we're coming.
answer: Okay.

question: ...Over 200 DEA field agents, a budget of almost 100 million dollars and state of the art communications equipment make the El Paso Information Center the Drug Enforcement Administration's flagship for the 21st century.
answer: Who are these guys?

question: Agents who died in the field. That house, that you see from the DEA headquarters, belonged to Porfirio Madrigal -- the Lord of the Skies, largest trafficker in Mexico.
answer: He died in a liposuction surgery, right?

question: Right. Now it's used by somebody from the Juarez Cartel, one of his lieutenants... Who knows? Every damn day there's birthday party. At first I thought they must have three hundred children, then I realized they're taunting us. Three miles away and we can't touch them. Ha, ha, ha.
answer: Who do we interface with on their side?

question: What do you mean?
answer: I mean, who runs interdiction on the Mexico side?

question: I don't know. I don't think there's any one person. See the problem is the Juarez cartel owns everything and everybody, all the property on the Mexican side, sometimes all the property on both sides. Warehouses, transportation, even tunnels. It's very organized.
answer: I want everyone thinking out the box for a second. What are we gonna do about Mexico? Come on, guys. Out of the box. Unlimited. Come on. I want to hear from everyone If I'm not mistaken, we got DEA, Pentagon, U.S. Attorneys office, about a billion dollars of budget right here. So what are you people waiting for?

question: On a clear day you can see Mexico City. This place is swept twice a day. I learned that in Miami in '85. Then the U.S. shut down the whole Caribbean, but it's a big game of wack-a-mole. Knock it down in Miami, it pops up here. And San Diego is so much more relaxing.
answer: Arnie, I need money. Somebody threatened my children. They want a first payment of three million dollars.

question: Helena, if I had it I would give it to you, but I don't have that kind of money.
answer: Arnie, help me. Doesn't anyone owe us money?

question: Yes, I told you before, there are people who owe you money but they're not paying. There's too much heat on Carl.
answer: Please. Tell me who Carl sells to.

question: Even if I knew I wouldn't tell you. You do not want to come into contact with these people. Only Carl knows who they are. That's his real asset. Ruiz doesn't know them. They don't know Ruiz. Church and State.
answer: What about legitimate businesses? We own a construction concern, real estate --

question: Laundromats for the washing of money. Unfortunately, Carl had only one successful business.
answer: Don't you have some good news? Isn't there something positive you could say. Sometimes I wonder what I'll do if Carl doesn't get out. I'm not very adept at being on my own. I've always had a man in my life. Always.

question: I remember when I first met you
answer: I'm glad you think so, but I'm picturing a debt-ridden, thirty-two year-old mother whose ex-husband is being compared to Pablo Escobar. And I'm wondering who would want to be with someone like that?

question: You two don't like me, do you?
answer: We don't have an opinion on you.

question: Maybe it's because I'm getting an apartment nicer than anything you'll ever see in your life? I can't believe the old man kept his promise.
answer: The General is a man of his word.

question: There's supposed to be someone here to let you in. Madrigal's alive.
answer: What?

question: Porfirio Madrigal is not dead. I just saw him.
answer: This is why Salazar is so interested in cleaning up Tijuana. Madrigal, who's supposed to be dead, owns him. And Madrigal is making a move on Juan Obregon.

question: Javi! Come on. Don't pull this you don't care bullshit. This is incredible information. It must be. Javi --
answer: We keep our mouths shut.

question: I think we may have found our Mexican Drug Czar. It's this General, Salazar. At least I'll have somebody on the other side I can talk to.
answer: Does this mean you're going to be gone more?

question: Possibly.
answer: You might want to pencil in a little face-time with your daughter.

question: Barbara --
answer: Because I'm at the edge of my capabilities, Robert.

question: The first thing we have to do is present a unified front.
answer: If you start in on the war metaphors I'm going to drive this car into a fucking telephone pole.

question: Look, I'm as worried as you are --
answer: No, I don't think so. Leave me alone, give me money. That's what I get from our daughter. She has a way of shutting me out that seems very familiar.

question: Yeah, well, she has a way of self- medicating that probably seems familiar, too.
answer: I'm not the one who has to have three scotches just to walk in the door and say hello.

question: I have a drink before dinner to take the edge off my day. That's different.
answer: Oh, it is?

question: Yeah, because the alternative is to be bored to death.
answer: Why don't you go in and tell your daughter how bored you are.

question: Caroline. Open this door immediately.
answer: Who is it? I'm going to the bathroom. One minute. Excuse me --

question: You're not going anywhere, young lady. Where is it? Where are the drugs? Where are they?
answer: Fuck you. I wasn't doing anything. You're like the Gestapo.

question: Fuck me? Oh, okay. Fuck me. Fuck you. I'm going to ask you one time to tell me the truth so that I can help you. Okay, young lady, that's it.
answer: Like I give a fuck.

question: What is wrong with you? What? You're going away. You're getting help somewhere.
answer: You can't make me.

question: Where are you taking me?
answer: Somewhere safe.

question: Where?
answer: A place we have, that we know is protected.

question: Not for me.
answer: Okay. Where would you like to go?

question: It's important that we work together. Mexico. America. One hand washing the other.
answer: We agree.

question: So... maybe you tell me about your informants in our operations.
answer: We thought maybe you'd have that kind of information for us.

question: This is a very different proposition.
answer: We pay for that kind of information. Is that what you're talking about, Javier?

question: How's David?
answer: How's David? How's David? He's terrific, Carl.

question: Helena --
answer: We watched his father get dragged away by federal agents. I don't even know how to begin to tell him where you are or when you're coming back... Or if you're coming back.

question: We'll get through this, I promise. I'll make it up to you --
answer: How? Supportive letters from prison while I'm being kicked out of our home? Do you have any idea what is happening out here? Our credit cards are maxed. The people at the bank, you should see their faces when I walk in there. I have a letter from the government telling me that anything I sell from our house will be taken against an income tax lien. Our friends are behaving like the crowd at a public hanging. Nobody will help us. Nobody will take us in. Nobody wants anything to do with us. So tell me, Carl, how you're gonna make it up to me. Tell me again how we'll get through this, and maybe while you're at it you can put your hand up against the glass so we can have a tender moment of connection.

question: Helena --
answer: Tell me what to do, Carl. I need guidance, not a fucking platitude. I'm not bringing a child into the kind of life I grew up with. I won't do it. I want our life back.

question: I recruited the best men in Mexico for my task force and put them through a rigorous screening process. Not only physical, but also psychological.
answer: I'd like to bring you up to Washington, walk you around our side of things, and share some of the information we've been able to develop on your cartels.

question: That would be very helpful to me. Also, I received the offer from DEA and the FBI to train some of my men at Quantico. I think this will be extremely useful, a good way for us to absorb some of your methods. I've been too busy to completely settle in.
answer: You've been making very good progress against the Tijuana cartel.

question: Yes, I am confident that Juan Obregon will be taken into custody before the end of the year. But, you must understand that it is very difficult because of corruption in the police force. We get a tip that he is one place, then we get there and he is already gone, having been warned by someone on our side.
answer: Hopefully the exchange of training methods and information between our countries will help with this problem.

question: Yes, I hope so as well.
answer: Let me ask you a related question. We've talked about the supply side, but what about demand? What is your policy for treating addiction?

question: Who is this?
answer: A friend... of Carlos Ayala.

question: Yes.
answer: I'm on a special phone, may I speak freely?

question: You may speak.
answer: I have a job for you and I don't have much time.

question: I love this place. Don't turn around. You were followed by the police, but they won't hear us over the children. I want to use a bomb.
answer: You're kidding. Can't you shoot him or something?

question: I don't really like guns. You shoot someone in the head three times and some doctor will keep them alive.
answer: When will you do it?

question: I don't know. Eduardo Ruiz is the only real witness against Carl. The security is very tight. There may not be a way.
answer: There's always a way. If people get to the Pope or the President, you can get to him.

question: What? What is it?
answer: It's very hard for me to come and tell you this. It's Manolo. He's going to do something stupid. I'm worried that he'll get himself killed. He's saying he's going to talk to the Americans. Become an informer.

question: Why does he need money?
answer: He has debts. He has gambling debts. He owes a lot of money.

question: How much?
answer: Nine thousand dollars.

question: What is he planning on telling them?
answer: Well, you know, he's going to say about Madrigal... and Salazar.

question: No, not yet.
answer: She's not at that place you sent her?

question: She snuck away. And we haven't seen her. She hasn't come home.
answer: Oh, man --

question: She hasn't called you?
answer: I tried to talk to her when she was up there, but they wouldn't put me through. I'm surprised she hasn't called.

question: Can you tell me anything? Do you have any ideas?
answer: I don't know what to say.

question: I'm not the police. I don't care about experimentation. She's a kid. I'm worried to death.
answer: You won't say anything to my parents?

question: I don't give a fuck about your parents --
answer: We sometimes went downtown to score.

question: What?
answer: The West End. We buy it off the streets. I can stop, you know, and she can't. Two people, really similar, we can talk about anything, but for me it's like a weekend thing, then I get my shit together, and for her it's different --

question: You don't know what the hell you're talking about. You're a cocky seventeen year-old and you don't have a clue what the stakes are. You don't know the value of the life you've yet to throw away. And neither does she. What do you mean, what do I want? I don't want anything.
answer: Hey man, I'm sorry. I'm just trying to help.

question: What the fuck do you want? You want some of that? What you gonna do to get some of that?
answer: Please --

question: What you gonna do? Maybe a taste. Feed this to you like a little bird.
answer: Don't --

question: Manolo, how are you?
answer: No. I'm looking for the waiter. I want to order.

question: What are you gonna have?
answer: A steak.

question: Well, if you like steak, we know a much better place. We'll take you there.
answer: That's okay, really. I was going to feed them wrong information. Feed them lies to... it was for... Don't tell Anna I died like this. Tell her it was something else. Tell her it was official business. Tell her that I died doing something honorable. Please, tell her that for me...

question: That was a stupid thing you did. Incredibly stupid.
answer: I tried, Arnie. And, I will continue to try.

question: Have you gone crazy? You are not Carl. You aren't as good as Carl. They are moving the trial to a high security location. The press has gone berserk. The jury will be influenced. Stay out of things. Let us try to win the case.
answer: That is going to be rather difficult when all the evidence is against us.

question: Helena, please. This is out of your hands.
answer: I know I made things worse. I know that and I'm sorry, but Arnie I need something from you. Something only you can help me with.

question: Helena --
answer: I need an introduction to the Obregon Brothers.

question: I can't do that.
answer: I figured out what Carl was up to and I need your help. Will you help me?

question: Mrs. Ayala. Thank you for coming. I am Juan Marquez, I work for Mr. Obregon. I believe you know my associate, "Tigrillo," the Little Tiger.
answer: Yes, he threatened to kill my five year-old son. I was under the impression I would be meeting Juan Obregon.

question: No, this is not possible. And I thank you for coming down here, though I suspect it's been a pointless journey.
answer: Why do you say that, Mr. Marquez?

question: I hear these stories. Your husband in jail. His business in chaos. Various people fighting over the scraps.
answer: My husband is the victim of an informer in your organization, not ours.

question: That is not true, Mrs. Ayala. Your route is compromised. Perhaps it is time for me to deal with other distributors in California.
answer: I don't think you're going to do that.

question: You don't? Listen to this woman in a man's world, a very violent world.
answer: There are plenty of other suppliers in Mexico.

question: But not in whose interest it is to help you out of debt.
answer: My husband had been working on something he called, The Project for the Children. Are you aware of this?

question: I don't know. Perhaps I remember something.
answer: We have the ability to change the color, odor, and physical property of cocaine.

question: You want to smuggle narcotics in Mr. Espastico Jacobo. That's nothing new.
answer: Not in... This doll is cocaine. Every part, from his ears to his accessory belt, is high-impact, pressure-molded cocaine. Odorless. Undetectable by dogs. Undetectable by anyone.

question: I don't believe you.
answer: Get a bowl. Try it.

question: You first.
answer: I'm six months pregnant. I won't do it.

question: Fine, then we don't have deal.
answer: Fine, then we don't have a deal.

question: Okay, okay. That's good coke.
answer: It should be... It's yours. I want our debt forgiven. I want to be the exclusive distributor of Obregon Brothers Cocaine for the United States. And I want the principle witness against my husband, Eduardo Ruiz, killed.

question: Perhaps... Perhaps... I'm afraid I must first ask you to pass a test. I asked the same of your husband and he succeeded with flying colors. Take this back with you. Deliver it safely to Tigrillo in San Diego and we have a deal.
answer: That's crazy. My husband is on trial for smuggling.

question: Exactly, and this is how I know I'm not getting into business with the U.S. Government.
answer: You will help me with my other problem.

question: Did you get it?
answer: What are you thinking, calling me at home with a message like that? You've compromised me and our relationship --

question: The place is swept twice a day. I learned that down in Miami in '85... Arnie. I'm the housewife. I belong to the most exclusive country club in La Jolla that accepts Latinos. Until recently, I believed my husband imported hydroponic strawberries, which I donated at the school fair. It's the same stuff? From the rainy day stash?
answer: It's the same. What happened to what they gave you?

question: Hello.
answer: I'm sorry... Did I wake you?

question: No, it's all right.
answer: Salazar's been taken down. He was working for Porfirio Madrigal.

question: What? I thought Madrigal was dead. I thought it was verified.
answer: Apparently not. Look, it's a shit storm here right now. When are you coming back? I don't know what to tell people any more.

question: I'll get there as soon as I can.
answer: If we're moving the press conference, we need to do it now. Are you all right?

question: Robert.
answer: I have to call you back.

question: The silver wedding cup. My Leica's gone.
answer: So's the video camera.

question: At least she's alive. Where are you going?
answer: She'll be at a pawn shop in an hour.

question: I don't know, maybe we missed her.
answer: I can't believe you used to bring my daughter here, to this place.

question: Hey man, back the fuck up. To this place. What's that shit? Right now, all over this country, a hundred thousand white people from the suburbs are driving around downtown asking every black person they see, You got any drugs? You know where I can get drugs? What kind of effect you think this has on the psyche of a black person, on their possibilities? If you sent a hundred thousand black people into your neighborhood, Indian Hills, and they asked every white person they saw, hey, you got any drugs?, within a day, your friends and their kids would be selling. It's market forces, man. The product's marked up three hundred percent. You can go out on the street and make five hundred bucks in two hours and then do whatever you want for the rest of the day. You think white people would still be going to law school?
answer: You're starting to piss me off. Get out of the car.

question: What do you want?
answer: I'm looking for my daughter, Caroline. She comes here.

question: This is a business. Get the fuck outta here.
answer: I need to find my daughter. I'll pay you.

question: Who the fuck do you think you are? Where the fuck do you think you are? Why the fuck do you think I shouldn't just put you in a dumpster?
answer: I have money --

question: I got money.
answer: I'll pay you a thousand dollars. I have it in my wallet.

question: I want your money, I'll take your money.
answer: Just tell me where she is.

question: Go shower. You smell.
answer: Fuck off.

question: Where's the love gone, Eddie?
answer: You expect me to be grateful for spending the rest of my life looking over my shoulder.

question: That thought makes me feel awful.
answer: Can't you for a second imagine none of this had happened? That my drugs had gone through. What would have been the harm? A few people get high who are getting high anyway. Your partner is still alive. We avoid having breakfast together. Don't you see this means nothing? That your whole life is pointless?

question: You're breaking my heart.
answer: The worst thing about you, Monty, is you realize the futility of what you're doing and you do it anyway. I wish you could see how transparent you are. This food tastes like shit.

question: So go shower already.
answer: You only got to me because you were tipped off by the Juarez Cartel, who's trying to break into Tijuana. You're helping them. You work for a drug dealer too, Monty.

question: The cocaine brand, 911, is an East Coast brand, a Juarez Cartel brand, and you must know it usually comes through into El Paso?
answer: I'm aware of that.

question: So what's it doing in Tijuana? Let me ask you a hypothetical question
answer: It could mean that, yes.

question: That would probably mean the Tijuana Cartel is gaining power?
answer: It's possible.

question: Is it possible to have a Drug Czar in Mexico who isn't connected in some war to one of the cartels?
answer: Yeah, it's possible... if you're prepared to die.

question: It's Saturday, Arnie. You work too hard.
answer: Carl, I'm running late. I'm coming right now --

question: Don't bother.
answer: What?

question: So Arnie, when were you going to tell me about the 3 million dollars we got in from San Francisco two days after I got arrested?
answer: I was just waiting for the right time.

question: And you didn't feel like you could trust my wife with this news?
answer: I just didn't want to take a chance. I didn't want to risk it. It could have been frozen along with everything else.

question: You had it all figured out. You move into my house. You raise my kids. You sleep with my wife. It was a good plan, Arnie.
answer: Carl, that's insane.

question: So my wife is lying?
answer: Carl, think about it, if I was trying to rip you off, I would have left town after Ruiz was killed. I wouldn't sit next to you in court listening to the dismissal.

question: Arnie, do think there's a difference between a reason and an excuse, because I don't think there is.
answer: Carl --
